 1. BACKGROUND A. COUNTRY BACKGROUND 1.1 Zambia is a country of about 750,000 square kilometers, roughly the area of Spain and the United Kingdom combined. With a population of some 9.2 million, it is one of the least densely populated countries in Africa. It is one the most urbanized countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, next to South Africa, with about 40 percent of the population living in cities and towns. Copper has been the backbone of the economy and has had a central role in determining the demographics of the country by creating urban centers in the Copperbelt that have drawn mine workers from the rural areas with the promise of jobs and easy access to infrastructure and social services. The proportion of the population living in poverty increased from 60 percent in the mid-1970s to 69 percent in 1991. 1.2 Zambia adopted an ambitious economic reform program in 1991 aimed at reducing the role of the state in the economy through decontrol, deregulation, and privatization and at promoting faster private sector growth through reduced fiscal deficits and a more efficient public sector focused on infrastructure and human development. The overall objective of this program is to reduce poverty through faster and more broadly shared economic growth and improved provision of social services. 1.3 Impressive progress has been accomplished in the past five years, especially in liberalizing markets and reducing the role of government in commercial activities. An ambitious privatization program is underway. Over half of the parastatals have been sold or liquidated, and negotiations are underway for the privatization of the copper mining parastatal. Control on prices, interest rates, imports, and exports have all been discontinued. 1.4 Macroeconomic performance has been uneven, particularly in the early years when inflation was over 100 percent, but fiscal and monetary control have been more effective in the past two years. The domestic budget achieved a small surplus in 1996. Progress on civil service reform has also been limited, but the size of the public service has begun to decline, and plans to restructure 14 ministries have been adopted, and implementation will begin in 1997. 1.5 The rate of economic growth was disappointing in the first five years of Zambia's economic reform program. Overall GDP has been about flat since 1990; per capita GDP has fallen by about 13 percent. Growth has been elusive because of incomplete and imperfect reform implementation, the inevitable delays in investor response, and several droughts, along with the considerable legacy of more than two decades of inefficiency and mismanagement from Zambia's previous policies. Overall GDP is estimated to have grown by about 5 percent in 1996, but only because good rains brought a 15 percent increase in agricultural GDP. 1.6 The country's economy has been, and is likely to remain, driven by the wealth of its natural resources. Copper will continue to play an important role in the economy, but diversification is needed. While the natural resource endowment could provide the basis for accelerated and broad-economic growth, its improper management would constrain growth and undermine efforts to alleviate poverty.
 -2- B. THE ENVIRONMENTAL SITUATION Importance of the Environment 1.7 Abundant water, land and forest resources could provide the basis for sustainable development in the country. However, increasing pressure on these resources has given rise to environmental degradation, constraints to growth and increasing poverty. The effects can be seen most directly in declining agricultural productivity, resulting from a lack of proper water and soil management; dwindling wildlife populations, as a consequence of poaching or degradation of their natural habitat; and declining fisheries earnings, as a result of overfishing and water pollution. Both air and water pollution affect the health and productivity of Zambia's work force, particularly in the urban areas surrounding mining operations. Many Zambians lack access to clean drinking water, adequate sanitation and solid waste management facilities. The adverse effects of these conditions on health and productivity tend to disproportionately impact the poor segments of society. 1.8 In recognition of the importance of the environment, the Government of Zambia has taken several steps toward its management. In 1985, it adopted a National Conservation Strategy, which laid the basis for the enactment of the Environmental Protection and Pollution Control Act in 1990 and the subsequent establishment of the Environment Council of Zambia (ECZ) as its statutory body. The Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MENR) was established in 1991 to set environmental policies and coordinate the ministries involved in environmental and natural resource matters. In December 1994, after a process of broad consultation, the Government finalized the National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) which identified key environmental problems and related institutional and legislative constraints, and recommended actions for management and mitigation.  -3 - Issues and Concerns 1.9 The five major environmental issues identified in the NEAP include: (a) soil degradation; (b) water pollution and inadequate sanitation; (c) deforestation; (d) air pollution, especially in copper mining towns; and (e) wildlife depletion. The framework for addressing these issues came out of a broad consultative process involving all segments of society. 1.10 Land. Agricultural land is abundant in Zambia, with only 6 percent of arable land currently under continuous cultivation. Nevertheless, the predominant soils in Zambia are low in nutrients, have low water retention capacities, and are generally strongly acidic. Land under cultivation is often subject to degradation as a result of erosion, deforestation, nutrient loss, and increasing of acidity levels. These problems, combined with a high rate of population growth (3.5 percent per annum) and policy-induced changes in access to land, land use and patterns of agricultural production, suggest a growing need to better manage agricultural land. 1.11 Water. Zambia is unusual in Southern Africa in that it is endowed with sufficient water resources to meet present and expected longer-term demands. Rainfall generally is good, groundwater is available everywhere in the country at less than 100 meters and reliable sources of surface water are abundant. However, recent droughts have pointed to the need for sustainable and sound management of water resources. While at present, there is no problem with the quantity of water resources in Zambia, conflicting water demands have arisen in some areas and environmental degradation has been increasingly observed. In the Kafue River Basin, for example, competing demands for hydropower generation, agricultural production, urban domestic and industrial use have created conflicts, and industrial waste in the Copperbelt and Kafue Estates has polluted much of the Basin. 1.12 Access to clean water and sanitation is a growing problem. It is estimated that 59 percent of the population has access to safe drinking water and that 55 percent has access to sanitation. There has been little extension of the country's urban water delivery infrastructure since the copper boom period ended. In response to this problem, the Bank is currently financing the Urban Restructuring and Water Supply Project to rehabilitate urban water and sanitation systems and rehabilitate small rural-piped systems. Water quality is also a cause for concern. In urban areas, increasing quantities of domestic waste and inadequate sanitation pollute groundwater supplies and surface water systems. Mining and industrial areas suffer from leaching of heavy metals and release of other forms of industrial waste into rivers. The country's extensive wetland ecosystems are also starting to be threatened. 1.13 Forest Resources. Forests and woodlands, which cover some 60 percent of the land area in Zambia, are rich in biodiversity but relatively poor in commercial timber species. Firewood and charcoal from these forests are the main cooking energy source for 90 percent of households. Deforestation, estimated at some 139,000 hectares per year in the period 1975- 1990, has reached critical levels as a result of uncontrolled settlement, illegal logging, clearing for agriculture and, to a lesser extent, shifting cultivation, forest fires, and charcoal production. Deforestation is a major contributor to soil erosion and siltation. 1.14 Air. Air quality is of increasing concern, especially in the mining areas. At present, sulfur oxide emissions from the mining industry rarely reach hazardous levels, though
 -4- concentrations near some mines routinely exceed the country's newly established air quality standards, and increased incidence of respiratory diseases has been recorded in the Copperbelt. Over the medium-term, it would be economically feasible to reduce emissions by converting sulfur oxides into industrial sulfuric acid which could then be used in the leaching process to recover copper from low grade oxide ores, however, substantial investment would be required. 1.15 Wildlife. Wildlife and unspoiled habitats are a rich national heritage, a source of livelihood for rural and peri-urban communities, and a potential source of significant tourism revenues. The country, rich in biodiversity, is believed to host 233 mammal, 731 bird, 145 reptile and 156 fish species. Zambia's fauna is protected in 19 national parks covering 6.4 million hectares, while regulated hunting is permitted in game management areas covering an additional 16.6 million hectares. The private sector operates another 19 game ranches. Wildlife is currently threatened by poaching, land-use pressures, development of economic infrastructure, mining, logging, overfishing, tourism development, bush fires, and the destruction of natural habitats. Traditional chiefs, who formerly ensured sustainable use of wildlife resources, no longer have legal power to do so. ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK Policy Context 1.16 Key policy orientations stemming from the National Conservation Strategy for Zambia and the NEAP include: * ensuring the sustainable use of Zambia's renewable natural resources; * maintaining Zambia's biological diversity, including the range of biological material governing the quality and productivity of domesticated plants and animals, the rich diversity of wild species, as well as essential ecological processes and life-support systems; * developing an understanding and public awareness of environmental issues, and reinforcing sound traditional practices to preserve natural resources and the habitat;
 -5- * fostering greater self-sufficiency within communities and building up their capacity to take control of their resources and environment; * gradually transferring the prime responsibility for environmental conservation and management from government to the people; and * tackling poverty as a root cause of environmental degradation and unsustainable use of natural resources. 1.17 In addition to these environmental policy orientations, the Government has recently taken a number of important policy initiatives which directly affect the implementation of programs in the environmental sector. Many of these initiatives are linked to the Public Sector Reform Program which is only now being implemented, after being formulated in late 1993. The three most critical policies and the implications of these policies are: * Restructuring the Public Service. The main thrust of the Public Sector Reform Program is to create a 'less costly, but more efficient Public Service,' which in practice means smaller government. * Decentralization and Strengthening of Local Government. The aim of this policy is to reduce the concentration of government by devolving powers and functions to the provinces and districts. Several ministries have already transferred staff and responsibilities to the districts. * Privatization. Consistent with the goal of 'small government' is the increased emphasis on the private sector and the transfer of responsibility for some services and agencies to the private sector, non-governmental and quasi-governmental bodies, as well as local communities. The move toward greater involvement of, and responsibility assumed by, communities is a direct consequence of this policy. Legislative and Regulatory Framework 1.18 The Environmental Protection and Pollution Control Act constitutes the overall umbrella legislation for the environment. Zambia also has a number of general and sectoral laws relating to environmental protection. Under ESP preparation, a comprehensive report assessed the legislation covering environmental management and environment-related sectors such as land, agriculture, health, forest, national parks and wildlife, local government, fisheries, international environmental cooperation, mines and minerals, and water resource management. The report shows that: (a) much of this legislation does not contain specific provisions and detailed criteria for the preservation and sustainable use of particular natural resources; (b) laws on economic development, natural resource management and environmental protection are not coordinated, with the exception of the Mines and Minerals Act of 1995, and the Mining Environmental Regulations of 1996, which require mining operators to comply with national environmental standards in mining operations; and (c) some penal and enforcement provisions in the legislation are outdated. 1.19 Furthermore, the report shows that the domestic legislation is not always consistent with the international environmental conventions that were ratified by Zambia, including: the 1968 Algiers Convention on Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources in Africa, the 1973 Washington Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora,
 -6- the 1985 Vienna Convention on the Protection of the Ozone Layer and the related 1987 Montreal Protocol, the 1989 Basel Convention on Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Wastes, the 1992 Rio Convention on Biological Diversity, the 1992 Rio Framework Convention on Climate Change and the 1994 Convention to Combat Desertification. Improvement of the legal framework would also have to ensure Zambia's full compliance with international environmental conventions. 1.20 The Government is currently reviewing various laws and their implementing instruments to update and improve the overall environmental legislation. The government, through ECZ, has enacted an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) 1997 legislation. It is also reviewing the legislation pertaining to forest and land tenure. 1.21 An effective policy and legislative framework for effective environmental management requires: (a) laying down standards and regulations that support current laws; (b) ensuring the consistency of environmental laws and related laws e.g., investment law, land tenure legislation; (c) building implementation capacity by training staff to carry out environmental management functions; and (d) ensuring effectiveness of the judiciary. Institutions 1.22 The sheer number and diversity of government agencies involved in environmental management highlight the need for coordination and clarity in functions and responsibilities. In addition to MENR, a number of ministries have significant environmental responsibilities: Mines and Minerals; Agriculture, Food and Fisheries; Lands; Energy and Water; Tourism, under which falls the National Parks and Wildlife Service; Local Government and Housing; and Education. Under the purview of the MENR, ECZ has the main responsibility for coordinating and managing environmental initiatives by these ministries and other agencies, and responsibility for technical management of the environmental mandate, while MENR is charged with high level coordination and policy direction. In addition to being empowered to oversee the implementation and enforcement of the environmental policies drafted by the Ministry, ECZ is also responsible for setting, enforcing and monitoring standards and measures of pollution control; maintaining an information network and database; facilitating environmental education and training; supervising the environmental impact assessment process; and, when necessary, implementing high priority and cross-sectoral environmental projects. 1.23 Since their inception, the two environmental apex institutions (MENR and ECZ), have been constrained by insufficient support from Government. ECZ, which relies on the government for its regular budget, has only managed to maintain its operations through donor support from the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) and the Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD). Only half of established positions have been filled. Some current staff have received training through bilateral programs but much remains to be done on training and capacity building to enable ECZ is to fully meet its mandate. However, the agency has achieved considerable success, particularly in the field of pollution prevention and protection. 1.24 At present, MENR has limited capacity to deal with environmental issues. Its two departments--forestry and natural resources--have contributed little to the Ministry's overall ability to carry out its environmental mandate. However, MENR has a number of competent officers with environmental experience who will be brought together in a new department, the
 -7- Planning and Information Department (PID). The establishment of this new departmnent, if matched with institutional support and training, would help address capacity constraints. 1.25 Through the ESP, the Government has committed itself to improving institutional performance by assigning clear institutional responsibilities in order to: (a) minimize opportunities for conflict among various agencies and bodies involved in environmental management; (b) better define the functions of relevant agencies; and (c) ensure effective coordination among government agencies and other actors such as local communities, NGOs and the private sector. D. THE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENDA 1.26 The NEAP outlines the Government's current agenda for coping with the key environmental issues and concerns presented above. Institutional and legal issues are at the forefront of this agenda. It is recognized that an effective, sustainable, prevention-oriented framework must be in place before irreversible environmental damage is done and the costs of remediation mount. While effective performance of MENR and ECZ are key to successfully achieving this goal, active and coordinated programs and initiatives by the sector ministries and agencies and cross-sectoral bodies such as the Ministry of Local Government and Housing (MLG&H) are also critical to sound environmental and natural resource management. 1.27 The main challenges lie in strengthening institutional and legislative capacities and frameworks; providing guidelines and enforcement mechanisms for sustainable natural resource management and environmental protection; coordinating and monitoring the activities of government, parastatal and private sector interests; and raising environmental awareness in the country and encouraging broader participation in the management of Zambia's natural heritage. 1.28 The Forest Act of 1973, the National Parks and Wildlife Acts of 1991 and, until recently, the Lands Act of 1975, tended to weaken traditional use and management systems.I This in turn has undermined incentives for local communities to manage their forests, wildlife and other resources. A return of custodianship of natural resources to local communities would restore the incentive to invest in and manage the resource base and local environment. Many of the programs designed to support local communities are uncoordinated (giving rise to duplication) and do not enable communities to deal adequately with environmental issues. Moreover, current understanding of the nature and magnitude of environmental and natural resource management problems facing Zambia is limited. There is a need for mechanisms to facilitate local interaction on environmental issues and provide financial resources and empower communities to manage their resources sustainably. The Land Act has since been revised in 1995 to address some of these issues. E. LESSONS LEARNED FROM PAST OPERATIONS 1.29 The Bank's assistance strategy for environmental management is based on a dialogue with the Government, lessons from previous Bank/IDA operations, and the Bank's global perspective on the environment. Although this is the first Bank Group lending specifically The Land Act was revised in 1995 while the National Parks and Wildlife Act and Forest Acts are in the process of being revised.
 -8- aimed at the environment in Zambia, much of the prior lending for the agriculture and urban infrastructure sectors has had a direct impact on the environment. The main lessons learned from these operations and other ESPs implemented in the region are: (a) avoid overly ambitious goals and minimize the inherent complexity of this kind of program; (b) set clear priorities through a process of consensus building and active stakeholder involvement; (c) promote community ownership through a highly participatory approach to program preparation and implementation; and (d) start with a modest and flexible first-phase program to progressively strengthen institutional capacity and initiate the process of change. These lessons are reflected in the proposed ESP. F. OTHER DONOR ASSISTANCE 1.30 Several donors and NGOs 2 (see Annex 5) have provided support for institutional strengthening, pollution prevention programs and other environmental initiatives. However, it is recognized that these initiatives must fit within a comprehensive regulatory and institutional framework if they are to be fully effective and their full potential realized. The present fragmentation of efforts and inefficient coordination mechanisms have been a constraint to the development of future donor support for the environment. Because of this situation, there has been a strong and coordinated support from the donor community for the joint Government/Bank initiative to develop the Environmental Support Program (ESP). G. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 1.31 Rationale for IDA Involvement. The program is in line with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) discussed by the Board on July 18, 1996, which supports a three pronged strategy to assist Zambia's development efforts: (a) help create a stable macroeconomic environment as a prerequisite for growth and employment; (b) promote private sector development and greater public sector efficiency to stimulate more rapid and inclusive growth; and (c) target assistance to poor and vulnerable groups directly. Effective environmental management is a critical feature of the second and third prongs of this strategy, as the sustainable management and use of Zambia's natural resources is fundamental for economic development and poverty reduction. Responding to the Government's request for Bank assistance provides an opportunity to help shape Zambia's regulatory and institutional framework, establish environmental policy and financial instruments, and ensure the integration of environmental concerns into Zambia's economy. The Bank, having supported the preparation of the NEAP, has already made a substantive contribution to improving environmental awareness but much remains to be done. Continued involvement of the Bank is essential to sustain the Government's commitment to difficult but critical changes in its public investment program and its reform of the civil service, including strengthening the capacity of districts to respond to community initiatives. The Bank also has a key role to play in helping the country mobilize Global Environmental Facility (GEF) financing, given the global nature of the benefits that are expected from improved biodiversity protection. The program follows successful introduction of ESPs in other countries. As one of the first environmental, stand-alone lending operations in Southern Africa, it could serve as a guide for other countries in the Region. 2 CIDA, IUCN, NORAD, UNDP, WWF and ZEEP.

PROGRAM RATIONALE 2.1 The program would support the objectives of both the Government's development strategy and the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy which seek to reduce poverty within the framework of economic growth and protection of the environment and natural resources. Within the NEAP's long-term perspective, the program would help the Government initiate a capacity building effort to better address environmental issues. This would be part of a long-term, multi-donor effort to finance projects and programs which have been generated by, or are in line with, the NEAP priorities and recommendations. While it is important that environmental issues be dealt with in an holistic manner, it is also essential that the responsibility for integrating and strengthening environmental initiatives in program implementation remains with sector ministries. Since existing institutions and the linkages between these institutions and other stakeholders are weak, it would be important for ESP to foster intersectoral linkages, promote capacity building at central and district levels, raise awareness, rationalize environmental legislation and mainstream the use of EIAs in investment operations. ESP would also contribute to the process, already underway, of empowering local communities in their role as custodians of the natural resource base and in tackling environmental issues of local concern. B. PROGRAM APPROACH 2.2 The approach taken in designing the ESP emphasizes active involvement of the various stakeholders in program formulation in order to build a sense of ownership and facilitate implementation. The approach has proved to be successful in a number of countries and has resulted in programs which are more in tune with local capacity, while also recognizing the particular constraints with which the stakeholders themselves have to contend. The ESP approach has been designed to allow considerable flexibility in implementation and responsiveness to priorities which might emerge during implementation. The support provided would form the first phase of a long-term commitment to the improvement of the environment and the sustainable use of natural resources. It would be limited in scope and ambition and would include a number of small and challenging pilot initiatives which, if successful, could be developed into full-fledged national activities. A similar approach was successfully employed with the Bank-supported Social Recovery Project (SRP) which, now in its second stage, is considered to be one of the model programs in the country. 2.3 The program would have an institutional focus. It would concentrate on building up the capacity of the two apex organizations and developing environmental awareness and management processes in sector ministries and agencies. As part of this focus, an environmental presence would also be established at the district level, on a pilot basis, to determine how a participatory environmental management capacity could best be developed in the communities. As part of the long-term decentralization effort, the goal should be to transfer progressively the responsibility for such management from Government to the communities. 2.4 The program would combine tightly targeted initiatives with more broadly applied ones. The targeted initiatives would be employed to direct support to the poorer members of society,
 -10- and to poorer communities in both rural and urban areas. It is the poor who often live in the most degraded areas and who, because of their condition and lack of options, contribute to environmental degradation. The provision of incentives to develop environmentally sound investment and income generating projects would enable communities to gradually reduce their poverty and adopt a more sustainable approach to resource utilization, thereby tackling poverty alleviation within an environmental framework. Along with targeted interventions, the ESP would support broad-based initiatives, such as the program on environmental education and public awareness and the development of environmental information systems, designed to foster a better understanding of environmental issues. 2.5 Inherent in program design is a multi-donor approach. The Bank's role is that of a facilitator and catalyst in the process, working with Government, the donors and other stakeholders to help design and prepare the ESP. The program, by creating a framework for tackling the concerns of the NEAP, would complement and reinforce the ongoing and planned activities of the core group of donors and NGOs already active in the environmental arena. Upcoming initiatives by two donors, NORAD and CIDA, would complement and be closely linked to ESP components. PROGRAM OBJECTIVES 2.6 The program will support the Government's development strategy of poverty reduction within the framework of economic growth and protection of the environment and natural resources. The program aims to mainstream environmental and natural resource management in Zambia's development processes at the national and local levels. At the national level, it will strengthen the institutional and regulatory framework for environmental protection and natural resource management. At the community level, it will strengthen local institutions and initiate a process to enable rural and urban communities to address natural resource degradation and capitalize on environmentally-sound investment opportunities. The key to the achievement of these objectives would be the development of mechanisms to foster the interchange of ideas, and the active participation and coordination of stakeholders at all levels. The lessons learned during the proposed ESP would be incorporated in the preparation of the second phase of NEAP implementation which would continue the process of institutional strengthening and expand environmental interventions in priority areas. Thereafter, within the agreed management structure, the detailed requirements for staff upgrading would be identified, training programs developed, and improved management practices spelled out. The EINMS would be oriented to problem solving, focusing on concrete environmental issues and targeting policies and intervention strategies. The network would also establish the foundation for progressively building a cost-efficient national Environmental Information System (EIS) that would make information for environmental decision-making in Zambia more readily available and accessible. Implemented at the district level, these information systems would seek to develop both technical capacity to build environmental databases and operational capacity to use them. The M&E would have three activities: (a) monitoring of key program performance indicators; (b) gathering information on key program management (disbursement, procurement), and (c) conducting impact evaluations, including beneficiary assessments, on a bi-annual basis.

PROGRAM IMPACT 5.1 The program intends to build capacity and improve the management of environmental resources by both the Government and the local communities in an effort to achieve sustainable development. The benefits from the program will be several. First, ESP will allow the Government to develop the national management capacity required to effectively implement and monitor the priority actions identified in the NEAP. Second, by dovetailing with ongoing activities, it will reinforce the environmental perspective of sectoral strategies and strengthen institutions in their ability to implement programs and enforce legislations. Third, the program will increase national and local awareness of the environmental consequences of economic policies and actions by conducting environmental impact assessments and implementing environmental awareness and education programs. Fourth, environmental management capacity building at the district level will facilitate the integration of environmental concerns into overall district development plans - an important priority as the decentralization process to the district level gathers momentum in Zambia. Fifth, the program will establish a process by which local communities will be empowered to achieve sustainable management of their natural resource base and to take action, through a grant matching facility, to reverse local degradation and improve the sustainable management of limited resources. Sixth, ESP will also bring a number of indirect benefits such as improvement of health and quality of life. Finally, the experience gained under ESP in environmental and natural resource management will be extended to other districts not covered under this program, thus adding a potential benefit of replicability. 5.2 While the program is not a targeted poverty reduction initiative, the positive implications for poverty reduction are substantial. Through its participatory Community Environmental Management Program and the PEF facility, ESP will target the most vulnerable households (in particular those headed by women) which are more likely to suffer from environmental degradation. The program will assist in improving their situation, both by preserving natural resources and by encouraging their better utilization. This, in turn, will generate direct economic benefits. In addition, ESP will bring a number of indirect benefits to the poor segments of society, such as improvements in health, and quality of life. B.  ANNEX 2 Page I of 12 ZAMBIA ENVIRONMENTAL SUPPORT PROGRAM Community Environmental Management Program Introduction 1. This Annex provides guidelines and an action plan for facilitating community participation in environmental and natural resource management which would form a basis for the identification. planning and implementation of local level activities within Zambia's Environlmental Support Program (ESP). 2. Environmenital and natural resource management is not and should not be viewed as the sole prerogative of goverinmenit. the involvement and empowerment of the resource users themselves is considered critical to the success of any environmental initiative. Furthermore, reliance on public or private sector law enforcement (often regarded as an alternative to community participation) is costly, inefficient and unsustainable. Experience worldwide has demonistrated that environmental management must be tackled as a joint venture between the genieral public and goverilnmeit. These principles have governed the design of support for promoting comimlunlity involvement under ESP. Objectives 3. The ESP aims to pilot a Community Environmental Management Program designed to develop mechianlisimis for involvinig rural and urban communities in environmental planning, decision-miiakinig and implementation. The program would raise community awareness of environimilental issues and, over time, develop community capacity to assume responsibility for lhe efficient, sustainable use of the resource base and the facilities and basic services it sustains. 4. To meet these overall objectives, the program would seek to: (a) assist in the creation of an enablinig environment at the national level for active community participation in environmienital issues: (b) strengthen the technical and financial capacity of rural and urban communities to deal with environmental matters at the local level and on their own behalf; (c) strengthien operational capacity in the major organizations associated with the environment (public sector -- especially at the district level -- SRP. NGOs, community-based organizations and the private sector): and (d) assist in the development and implementation of a series of simple Community Environmental Action Plans (CEAP). Approach 5. Rather than setting out a single blueprint for mobilizing a large number of communities, the Community Environmental Management Program would initially test and develop techniques on a limited scale to help communities in selected pilot districts to design their respective CEAPs. The CEAPs would form the framework within which a series of small-scale, community-based environmental initiatives could be financed through the Pilot Environmental Fund (PEF) and/or other relevant sources. Experience gained under the pilot program would
 ANNEX 2 Page 2 of 12 enable the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MENR) and other collaborating government and non-government agencies at national, provincial and district levels to: (a) determine how best to identify, design, implement and monitor programs and projects in partnership with local communities; and (b) establish a sound basis for subsequent program expansion. 6. The establishment of an environmental presence at the district level would be central to this process. Under the program, a new district level position of Environmental Facilitator would be piloted in one district in each of the nine provinces in Zambia. The facilitators, who would be trained in participatory methods, would be contracted by MENR and assigned as technical advisers on the environment to the respective District Councils. District Council representatives would assist the MENR, ECZ, SRP and MLG&H in drawing up Terms of Reference for the facilitators. These would, inter alia, define facilitators' accountability, duties and reporting responsibilities. The Districts Councils would participate fully in the recruitment of their respective facilitators who would serve as the focal point for all environmental initiatives in a district including, but not restricted to, activities supported through ESP components. More specifically, they would: (a) be involved in the participatory process through which communities would develop their CEAPs; (b) act as a broker for the communities in establishing links with district technical staff, NGOs, donors and the private sector; (c) act as a catalyst for environmental activities in the district; and (d) bring together ESP facilities and services in support of environmental initiatives in the district, in particular, those available under the PEF and Environmental Education and Public Awareness (EEPA) components. Facilitators would receive regular training to improve work performance and update their skills based on lessons learned through ESP and in programs elsewhere in the region. 7. The facilitators for the initial two pilot districts would be contracted in project year 1. Tlhe remaining facilitators would be recruited at the end of project year 1 and trained by working alongside their colleagues in the two initial districts throughout project year 2. Once trained, they would begin operations in their respective districts. The actual rate of program expansion from project year 3 onwards would be determined during Mid-Term Review. Participatory Community-Based Planning Process 8. The design of the proposed process takes into account existing, albeit limited, experience of engaging communities in environmental management in Zambia, and experience with similar programs operating elsewhere in the region. The process is intended to permit flexibility in implementation and may be adapted and modified as experience of working with communities grows and the knowledge and understanding of Zambia's environment deepens. 9. In the initial year of developing the Community Environmental Management Program, pilot communities would be selected in which environmental concerns, particularly those identified in the NEAP, are known to be pre-eminent. In such cases, the process of CEAP preparation and micro-project identification would begin with a participatory 'environmental needs assessment' in which attention would focus from the outset on natural resource and environmental management. The process would involve a sequence of defined steps, although local variants would be expected to emerge as dictated by location-specific circumstances. 10. Step 1 - District Selection. The program requires early successes in order to build credibility and stimulate other communities to participate. The program would select the pilot
 ANNEX 2 Page 3 of 12 districts on the basis of a core set of technical and social criteria including association with one or more of the key environmental problems identified in the NEAP - water pollution, air pollution, deforestation, land degradation, wildlife depletion; level of poverty; and health and nutritional status. These would be developed by MENRJPID and ECZ in consultation with the other institutions to be represented in the ESP Program Management Group. Additional criteria, such as the presence of motivated and interested district line officials, the presence of interested communities and traditional leaders, likelihood of success, and accessibility, would be used to guide the final selection. 11. Step 2 - Launch of the Community Environmental Management Program in the District. The Environmental Facilitator would be responsible for coordinating launch workshops for district council and line ministry officials, NGOs, church groups, traditional leaders, and interested members of the private sector. These workshops would aim to inform participants of ESP objectives, its components and the opportunities it presents, and involve them in developing the Program in their districts. One of the outputs of these workshops would be to develop an agreed set of criteria to aid the selection of communities in the district. 12. Step 3 - Selection of Participating Communities. Using the recommendations of the launch workshops as a basis, the Environmental Facilitator would work closely with the district administration as well as traditional leadership to identify four initial communities. These communities will have recognized the need for action in environmental control/management and will have expressed an interest in accessing resources for environment-related investment. For overall program planning purposes, it has been assumed that four new communities would become engaged under the program in each district in each year of the ESP. Implementation experience may suggest a need to modify the assumed rate of expansion. 13. Step 4 - Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) Training and the Development of CEAPs. International Environmental/PRA Specialists would train a suitably qualified Zambian national team in a wide range of environmental and natural resource management issues and adapted PRA techniques suited to use in urban as well as rural communities. With the assistance of the facilitator, the national team would develop participatory appraisal skills among local NGOs (where available), local line ministry officials and other individuals as appropriate (teachers, community leaders, community facilitators, businessmen). Initial theoretical training would be followed by practical, field-based training (learning by doing) while carrying out the first community environmental needs assessment. Trained local groups would carry out subsequent needs assessments in a district with further training and support from the national team as necessary. Environmental Facilitators would help guide the assessments, particularly in the early stages of the program. The national PRA team would initiate similar training processes in other districts under ESP in accordance with the phased expansion of the Community Environmental Management Program. 14. The environmental needs assessment would lead to the preparation of a CEAP within which a number of priority investment requirements may be identified. The Environmental Facilitator would act as a broker, helping communities to contact appropriate sources of support, such as the PEF, EEPA, SRP, programs of sector ministries at district level, and the Rural Investment Fund. An indicative list of the types of micro-projects which may be considered for PEF financing is given in Attachment 1. In guiding the communities, the ESP program would avoid duplication and competition between different funding sources by reference to the
 ANNEX 2 Page 4 of 12 eligibility criteria of the respective funds. Proposed eligibility criteria for the PEF/Community- Based Initiatives Fund are given in Attachment 2 15. The Environmental Facilitator would help communities wishing to apply for PEF matching-grants to meet necessary pre-qualification conditions, complete funding applications and submit micro-project proposals to the PEF Secretariat (Attachment 3). During the initial pilot phase, the PEF Coordinator would assist in the district level desk and field appraisals of potential micro-projects. Where required, funds would be made available from PEF resources to refine the technical and investment plans of micro-projects. The process from micro-project appraisal to matching-grant approval by the PEF/MPU Steering Committee would take no longer than 6 months. More than one micro-project could be eligible for funding in each CEAP. Potential micro-projects would be prioritized by the communities and their implementation phased taking into account communities' implementation capacity. 16. Step 5 - CEAP Implementation. A key pre-qualification requirement for communities to receive a PEF matching grant would be the establishment of a Micro-Project Committee to manage the activities on behalf of the community and operate a bank account for the micro- project. The Committee may elect to manage its own activities or to contract services from a locally-based NGO or other local specialist(s) to provide technical and/or other services. The facilitator would assist as necessary with arranging the contracts. Subsequently, both the Committee and the facilitator would monitor project implementation progress. The facilitator would assist communities to access additional technical assistance as required and, together with a contracted local technical team appointed by the District Council, evaluate the project upon completion. On an annual basis, the CEMP review would incorporate beneficiary assessments of micro-project impact and the effectiveness of the participatory environmental management process as a contribution to the overall management information system of ESP. Benefits of the Community Program 17. Implementation of the Community Environmental Management Program and the experience gained in developing participatory environmental methods would have benefits at community, district and national levels as follows: * Community Capacity Building. The formation of Micro-Project Committees which manage their own funds, and communities' collaboration with NGOs and other local experts in solving environmental problems, would be expected to raise environmental awareness and improve financial and technical management skills at the local level. This in turn would increase communities' confidence and ability to tackle other community problems. Training of the Micro-Project Committees in accounting procedures would give communities an opportunity to manage their funds effectively and responsibly. In the longer term, such experience could allow the feasibility of creating Community Development Funds to be explored; * District Capacity Building. Elected district officials, line ministry representatives, NGOs, and the private sector would participate in the environmental/natural resource management and PRA training on the district level. They would also take part in PRAs in their districts in collaboration with the Environmental Facilitators. This would increase the level of environmental awareness in the district and develop the technical environmental skills of district technicians from both the private and public sectors. These skills and experiences
 ANNEX 2 Page 5 of 12 could be drawn upon in future phases of ESP for promoting the expansion of similar programs within their own districts as well as in other districts; and National Level Benefits. The Community Environmental Management Program would help keep MENR and ECZ in touch with environmental and natural resource management problems and concerns as perceived by communities. In addition, the program will begin the process of gradual transfer of responsibility for environmental and natural resource management from government to the user, thus reducing the burden on government and facilitating sustainable management of the environment. The experiences gained through the program during the initial phase of ESP would provide a sound basis on which MENR could plan participatory environmental programs on a broader front in subsequent phases of ESP. As part of the ESP 1 review of the effectiveness of community-based initiatives and in support of ESP2 preparation, MENR would be in a position to conduct a series of policy review workshops. The workshops would bring together representatives of Micro-Project Committees, district administration, national policy makers, national and international NGOs and technical experts to discuss their conclusions on the participatory processes tested and developed through the community program. The workshop output would be to recommend future directions for the private/public sector partnership in environmental and natural resource management. Community program implementation experience and workshop recommendations would serve as the basis for designing further legislative and policy reforms. Finally, the availability of environmental skills within its management structure would enable SRP to consider environmental activities in developing its programs with communities in the ESP pilot districts.

 ANNEX 2 Page 9 of 12 Attachment 2 PEF Eligibility Criteria Eligibility Criteria for the Community Based Initiatives Fund The eligibility criteria are defined to encompass initiatives which tackle natural resource and environmental problems in rural and urban communities. During the process of CEAP preparation, environmental facilitators would orient the communities to the PEF operational guidelines and eligibility criteria for financing, and would assist communities to develop proposals which fulfill the criteria. The PEF would consider proposals for matching grants to support community-based micro-projects which: * are technically in line with the priority natural resource and environmental management concerns guiding ESP and identified through the National Environmental Action Plan; * promote the sustainable management of natural resources and/or environment in either the short- or long-term; * tackle natural resource and/or environmental problems and priorities which have been clearly identified as part of the CEAP preparation process; are consistent with district environmental priorities; and have been endorsed by the District Environmental Committee, District Development Coordinating Committee and the District Council; * are technically feasible given the circumstances of the applying community; * demonstrate that the micro-project will benefit the poor and other vulnerable groups; * have a direct economic benefit; * are cost effective; * are submitted by a Micro-Project Committee which has been specially established with an elected Chairman, Treasurer, and Secretary, and a membership in which men and women are equally represented; * demonstrate the community's commitment to, and ownership of, the micro-project through its willingness to pay some 25% of the associated costs, either in labor, kind or cash. The proportion to be contributed by the community may vary according to the nature of the activity but would be worked out with the community during micro-project design; * demonstrate that the majority of the community and future beneficiaries recognize the importance of the long-term sustainability of the micro-project by committing themselves to setting up a Community Maintenance Committee before micro-project completion. The costs of future operation and maintenance would be the full responsibility of the community; and * require funding support from a PEF matching-grant not exceeding US$20,000. More typically, a micro-project is expected to cost in the order of US$5,000 - 10,000.

doc.abstracts: The Environmental Support Project will support the Government's development strategy of poverty reduction within the framework of economic growth and protection of the environment and national resources. The program aims to mainstream environmental and natural resources management in Zambia's development processes at the national and local levels. The program will have four major components: a) institutional strengthening and legal framework as well as piloting a community environmental management program; b) environmental education and public awareness (EEPA); c) pilot environmental fund (PEF) to instigate an incentive mechanism, promote community-based microprojects, finance studies and develop action plans and strategies; and d) environmental information management supporting the establishment of an Environmental Information Network and Monitoring System (EINMS) and a monitoring, evaluation and reporting system as a management tool for project.
